awd_titl_txt: US-Korea Workshop: International Cooperation in Particle, Nuclear and Astrophysics Research
awd_abstract_narration:
We propose to hold a US-Korea joint workshop on Particle, Nuclear and Astrophysics Research in Seoul, Korea on April 16-17, 2012. This workshop will immediately precede the Korean Physical Society (KPS) Spring meeting. This workshop would bring together over 40 leading researchers, postdocs and graduate students in particle physics, nuclear physics and astrophysics from across the U.S. and Korea. It would provide an opportunity for these communities to initiate long-term collaborations regarding the Korean plan to construct a heavy ion accelerator, KoRIA (Korea Rare Isotope Accelerator) and a Basic Science Institute (BSI) as part of the International Science & Business Belt (ISBB).

This workshop will serve as a timely event to bring together U.S. and Korean researchers from academia, laboratories, and industries for discussion of future collaborations in Particle, Nuclear and Astrophysics research. It can help develop a near and long-term plan for KoRIA to serve as a world-class facility that would benefit scientists world-wide. Participating graduate students and post-docs will benefit from exposure to internationally recognized leaders in the field, which will help their career development. The resulting collaborations would involve students in both countries and promote their active exchanges. Other areas such as medical imaging and radiation detection technology will undoubtedly benefit from advancement in the accelerator and detector development. Under-represented groups such as women in science will be actively involved in this workshop.

por.por_cntn:
A US-Korea joint workshop on Particle, Nuclear and Astrophysics Research was held in Daejeon, Korea, April 24-25, 2012. This workshop immediately preceded the Korean Physical Society (KPS) Spring meeting, where the 60th Anniversary of KPS was celebrated. This workshop was organized by E. S. Seo of the University of Maryland (UMD), C. R. Ji of North Carolina State University and J. Yu of University of Texas, Arlington, in the US, and S. Nam of Kyung Hee University and B. H. Lee of  Sogang University in Korea. UMD provided secretarial support for the U.S. travelers, and Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology provided the meeting venue. This workshop brought together 73 participants, almost twice the number initially planned, including leading researchers, postdocs and graduate students in particle physics, nuclear physics and astrophysics from across the U.S. and Korea. There were 12 women participants, 14 postdocs, and 10 Graduate Students. Some of the U.S. participants including young postdocs and students also made presentations at the KPS Spring meeting.

This joint workshop focused on  fundamental topics, such as the nature of the nuclear force, which binds protons and neutrons into stable nuclei and rare isotopes. It addressed the origin of simple patterns in complex nuclei, the nature of neutron stars and dense nuclear matter, the origin of the elements in the cosmos, and the nuclear reactions that drive stars and stellar explosions. Experimental methods to understand these questions were presented and discussed. In addition, the workshop focused on what comprises matter, what its fundamental constituents are, and how these constituents are interconnected.  This workshop was a timely event for construction of KoRIA (Korea Rare Isotope Accelerator) and the Institute for Basic Science (IBS), as part of a mega project called the International Science & Business Belt (ISBB). A web tool, Integrated Digital Conference (Indico), developed by the CERN Document Server Software Consortium, was used for archival of conference information. The full agenda and presentation files can be found at the workshop scientific program link. In addition, meeting photos and other data uploaded by participants are documented on the web.

In addition to the travel support provided by the NSF, the workshop was sponsored by KPS and research centers including Center for Quantum Spacetime (CQUest), RCMST, KNU/WCU, Korea CMS, KAIST, KIAS, KISTI, and SKKU, in Korea.
